text: The answer it’s very long and it’s based on my own experience... now things can be changed a bit
Personally was not a real choice to be a generalist and to work in many different fields and company... was a necessity

When I started my career the industry was very different and especially in Italy (where I come from) was not quite well developed, there were not that many studios or opportunity.
So for that reason I need to adapt myself to do many things.
I studied in a school where I leavened a bit of everything (but a very little bit) and at the time the thing I liked the most was modelling.

When I started in a small Advertising/Commercial company in Milan we were only two guys working on the VFX; he was the senior with a couple of years of experience and I was the newbie. The combination between us was quite good cause he was the “artist” dealing with concept, animation, art direction and I was the more “technical” one, dealing with the other aspect of the CG, modding, texturing, shading and lighting.
This situation together with my extreme curiosity pushed me to improve myself and learn a lot of things in a very limited amount of time.
Long story made short I became a generalist.

Answering briefly your question when you change from one studio to another you need to have a great flexibility; you need to learn new tools a new pipeline/workflow as fast as possible. Big companies have more robust/established pipeline and usually they give you a week or two of training time; smaller studio as a more “agile” pipeline more flexible workflow but they rely much more on your personal skills to solve the issue.
So its a combination of training on the job and studying from home.
One thing I love of this job is that is in continue evolution and you never stop to study and learn... if you want to remain at the top ;-)
